--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "shanemcdonaldryan" <shanemcdonaldryan@=
...> wrote:
>
> Spent quite a bit of time working on this problem. Not too =
successful.
> 
> Go to Metatrader4.com and learn the meta trader language (=
pretty much c). It will allow you create scripts and backtest with historic=
al data to see how they perform. If you write a DLL you can even call NEAT =
via Metatrader.
> 
> I used to work for a company trading futures and I can=
 tell you all the easy data mining type trading strategies are tapped out. =
You'll have to find something interesting to make it work. Ideally some sor=
t of leading indicator or something very strongly co-ordinated so you can d=
o pairs trading.
> 
> Sliding window would be my advise. But that is a pret=
ty inconsequential detail as you'll need much more than a sliding window to=
 make money in my experience.
> 
> Tell me how you do and I can give you my=
 advice. Though take it with a grain of salt because I didn't make my billi=
ons through this :)
> 
> Regards,
> 
> Shane
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.c=
om, "gururise" <gururise@> wrote:
> >
> > Hello,
> > Browsing the archives,=
 its obvious other's have worked on this problem using NEAT with varying de=
grees of success.  I'm using the rtNeat C++ package under linux and am tryi=
ng to evolve a time-series predictor applicable to either the stock market =
or forex markets.
> > 
> > Most of the published research used Neural Netwo=
rks trained via backprop.  These networks typically used a sliding window t=
echnique. For example, if you have 1000 days of historical data, a sliding =
window of 100 would feed the first 100 days of data as input, and the 101st=
 day would be the predicted output from the net. Then the window would slid=
e by 1 day, and you feed the next 100 days and so on an so forth.  
> > 
> =
> I've been trying to use a similar technique with NEAT with very limited s=
uccess.  For inputs, I use change in price and normalized volume.  The fitn=
ess function is basically the inverse of the mean squared error of the pred=
icted outputs vs. the actual data.  The output is trying to predict the cha=
nge in price at the next time period (it could be positive or negative).  I=
've also switched from the default sigmoid activation function to a bi-pola=
r sigmoid activation that allows for outputs in the range of [-1,1].
> > 
>=
 > How are others using NEAT for time series prediction?  Are you using a s=
liding window technique, or just have a large input with one output?  Has a=
nyone had success using NEAT to evolve a time-series predictor?
> >
>
